title: Corners in Quasirandom Groups via Sparse Mixing

The notion of quasirandom groups was introduced by Gowers  in studying product-free sets. A finite group G𝐺G is D𝐷D-quasirandom if every nontrivial irreducible representation over ℂℂ\mathbb{C} has dimension at least D𝐷D. One can show that every irreducible representation of a finite group G𝐺G must have dimension at most |G|𝐺\sqrt{|G|}. We record this fact for later use, which can be found in most introductory texts on representation theory of finite groups. For example, this follows from Proposition 5 in [48, Chapter 2.4]. Every complex irreducible representation of a finite group G𝐺G has dimension at most |G|𝐺\sqrt{|G|}.
